section.name: STR & COMP ADVANTAGE: Strategy and Competitive Advantage

comments:
MGMT 701 is designed to be an upper-level course in strategy. It provides new concepts and ideas for the tool-kit of the manager involved in the strategy process. We start out with the question of how value can be created and, more importantly, appropriated. This leads to the general issue of how a competitive advantage can be built. We will focus in our discussion on new concepts that have been developed around the notions of complementarities and fit. In the next section of the course, we look at the question of what decisions managers can make to sustain a competitive advantage. In the last section of the course, we will be dealing with strategy making in the face of environmental changes.

An overwhelming majority of students thought that this class was definitely “one of the better ones they had taken at Wharton, if not ever.” They would recommend it to everyone regardless of their majors and claim that you will come out of it with a “stronger understanding of business strategy and businesses in general.” 

Students also agreed that Professor Sigglekow was “the most incredible professor” they’ve ever had. Some even said that they would be surprised if there was a “better professor at Wharton.” Everyone agreed that they learned a great deal from Professor Sigglekow, although he could be a little rude and defensive in class. Students also thought he did a magnificent job facilitating case study discussions in class.

As far as course load is concerned, students felt that the group paper was “hard to manage” and would prefer an individual or take-home final assessment. Students also thought that class participation should be given a heavier emphasis in this class, although some disagreed because they only met for a few set times.
